rev.comment: rm unnecessary screenshot of google's current home page. there's already a screenshot above; another one here is unnecessary.

Line 39: Line 39:
:''Main article: [[History of Google#Growth|History of Google (Growth)]]''
:''Main article: [[History of Google#Growth|History of Google (Growth)]]''
According to the Nielsen cabinet, Google is the most used [[search engine]] on the web with a 54% market share, ahead of [[Yahoo!]] (23%) and [[Windows Live Search]] (13%). However, independent estimates from popular sites indicate that between 70%<ref>''[[Rich Skrenta|Skrenta, Rich.]] "[http://www.skrenta.com/2006/12/googles_true_search_market_sha.html Google's true search market share is 70%]." ''[http://www.skrenta.com/ Skrentablog]'' [[January 22]], [[2007]].</ref> and 80% <ref>''[[Hedger, Jim]] "[http://www.enquisite.com/blog/2006/12/18/search-engine-market-shares/ Search Engine Market Shares]." ''[http://www.enquisite.com Enquisite]'' [[January 22]], [[2007]].</ref> of search referrals come from Google, with Yahoo! a distant second and Windows Live Search occupying barely 5%. The Google search engine receives about a billion search requests per day.
According to the Nielsen cabinet, Google is the most used [[search engine]] on the web with a 54% market share, ahead of [[Yahoo!]] (23%) and [[Windows Live Search]] (13%). However, independent estimates from popular sites indicate that between 70%<ref>''[[Rich Skrenta|Skrenta, Rich.]] "[http://www.skrenta.com/2006/12/googles_true_search_market_sha.html Google's true search market share is 70%]." ''[http://www.skrenta.com/ Skrentablog]'' [[January 22]], [[2007]].</ref> and 80% <ref>''[[Hedger, Jim]] "[http://www.enquisite.com/blog/2006/12/18/search-engine-market-shares/ Search Engine Market Shares]." ''[http://www.enquisite.com Enquisite]'' [[January 22]], [[2007]].</ref> of search referrals come from Google, with Yahoo! a distant second and Windows Live Search occupying barely 5%. The Google search engine receives about a billion search requests per day.
â
[[Image:Google_2007.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Google 2007 Home Page]]
+
While the company's primary market is in the web content arena, Google has begun to experiment with
While the company's primary market is in the web content arena, Google has begun to experiment with
other markets, such as [[radio]] and print publications. On [[January 17]], [[2006]], Google announced that it had purchased the radio advertising company dMarc, which provides an automated system that allows companies to advertise on the radio.<ref>Levingston, Steven. "[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/01/17/AR2006011701333.html Google Buys Company To Expand Into Radio]." ''[[Washington Post]].'' [[January 18]], [[2006]].</ref> This will allow Google to combine two niche advertising media -- the Internet and radio -- with Google's ability to laser-focus on the tastes of consumers. Google has also begun an experiment in selling advertisements from its advertisers in offline newspapers and magazines, with select advertisements in the [[Chicago Sun-Times]].<ref>Gonsalves, Anton. "[http://www.informationweek.com/industries/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=175803378 Google Confirms Testing Ads in Sun-Times Newspaper]." ''Information Week.'' " [[January 10]], [[2006]].</ref> They have been filling unsold space in the newspaper that would have normally been used for in-house advertisements.
other markets, such as [[radio]] and print publications. [[January 18]], [[2006]].</ref> This will allow Google to combine two niche advertising media -- the Internet and radio -- with Google's ability to laser-focus on the tastes of consumers. Google has also begun an experiment in selling advertisements from its advertisers in offline newspapers and magazines, with select advertisements in the [[Chicago Sun-Times]].<ref>Gonsalves, Anton. "[http://www.informationweek.com/industries/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=175803378 Google Confirms Testing Ads in Sun-Times Newspaper]." ''Information Week.'' " [[January 10]], [[2006]].</ref> They have been filling unsold space in the newspaper that would have normally been used for in-house advertisements.
